bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, October 12, 1910

div1.p: Carter describes his travels in Belgium and his impressions of the Exposition.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, October 12, 1910
div1.opener:
TELEPHONES
1436-9117
Ascenseurs
LIFT
Antognoli Preres
PROPRIETAIRES
HÔTEL DE L'ESPERANCE
BRUXELLES,
(MIDI)
Le 12. October 1910
Dear Mrs Laura:
div1.p:
I am in a certain amount of
trouble & yet I have escaped a worse one.
I came here this morning about 8..12 A.M.
from Antwerp - I wanted to see the Am.
Minister on some international trouble at
Antwerp. & go on to Havre tomorrow - on
the same train I left. The minister, whom
I did not really want to see, is on his va-
cation & the Secretary of Legation for
whom I asked was attending an Art
Congress - by order of the State Depart. - some
where in Brusselles. The Secretary who is
usually the man who does the work of
the Legation & whom I therefore wanted to see-
in Grant Smith. L's Chileno acquaintance
I remember now that she told me he was
here as secretary - but I had forgotten it.
Strange that the only Legation I am likey to
visit should be where he is. He is well
thought of here. I met no one save a very
modest well behaved clerk - a boy - a-
bout 21 or 22 years old but young for his
years. We had a pleasant chat but it did
not seem necessary to talk business to
him - or advisable. Gave it up

On my return I find that there is a
general strike on the R. R. in the North
of France & that if I had not stop-
ped in Brussels - I had stopped in
Paris - or maybe at Amiens this
side - & from neither place could I
have gone out in any direction.
Here I will wait until tomorrow & if
it is not reasonably sure that I can get to
Havre I will return to Antwerp & thence
to Hamburg & finish up that end of the
line leaving Havre & Cherbourg to
the last & sail home from the latter port
instead of from Hamburg; I mean sail
for home, so you see while it is a
nuisance. It is far better than if I had
gone on to Amiens or Paris, If I can see
Mr. Smith tomorrow I will wait over a-
nother day - If I can not I think I will
start for Hamburg in the afternoon.

I came over here Sunday to the Expo-
sition - but it was a dark cloudy day,
& I was feeling out of sorts besides. I saw
a good deal but enjoy it I did not
Only stayed from 8.30 to 2.00, - It is a 1/2
hours run & the round trip - 2d class - 4.50 f.
= 86 cents - 1 fr. entrance, & .40 f. street car fare
& .20 for a map of the grounds. Today was bright
& I felt well & I spend as long or longer
time there, & saw 5 times as much I on
I only attempted to see the French & Ital-
ian exhibits - because I wanted to see
beautiful, not extraordinary things,
The exhibit of Geraniums - was a
wonder & some of the French Roses I
likewise. They must have been won-
derful a month ago. There are three4
divisions of gardens - Belgium: Hol-
land: Germany & France: S Individ-
ual florists having Plats - There were
some fine flowers - Karl Druskis & a large
bl flesh colored Rose - I did not know - in
the Luxemburg exhibit - (Germanside)
“Kitten Freŕes” were the florists. But there
was nothing to compare with the exhibit
of Guillot: Verdier & the Lyons Rosarians
yet the place, or time, was too damp for Roses,
& too cold. The Dahlias too were beauti-
ful - & of these the French were also, in my
judgment the best, although Holland
was a good second; hergeraniums were the finest.

What really was however the most
beautiful & most artistic dine exhibit
I saw was - don't laugh - the
dressmakers models - wax my dear
I am sorry to say - dressed up in the French
section: Reverton: Red fern: Pinand (I
think “Pinand”) & Revillon & had a number
of others had a lot of wax models
which were artistically beautiful.
They were beautifully dressed & the
dresses became the style the face
as well as the figure, - of the model &
they were graceful in pose, & were a-
bout to move, even if they did not
They had expression, & a haughty
face, would be on a model with a
haughty carriage & pose & be dressed
in character. It really was a beauti-
ful & artistic exhibit - one or two
only were out of place relation with their
clothes. They - the French - are surely an ar-
tistic people.

None of the pictures are in the Ex. proper-
- which I did not know - except a few of the
works of Rubens - in the “Rubens Heris” a
replica of his house & extremely interes-
ting. In this are the original pictures
which he kept himself - a small sized
“Descent from the Cross” & some others.
Some of them - 2 at any rate are no credit
to him. If I stay over tomorrow - I will
do so for the purpose - I will go to the old
palace - where there is a full - very full-
collection of the Flemish school. Rubens:
Teniers: Vandyke: Jordaens the van Eyks & some
one or two others. The pictures have been
loaned from other than Flemish Gal-
leries. Dresden: Munich: London & Paris.
It is only Flemish Art however & early
Flemish art.

Yesterday I spent about 1 1/2 hours be-
fore the “Descent from the Cross” in the
Antwerp Cathedral. It has neither
the passion nor the Conviction that a
Spanish or Italian painter or a German either had put
in it. I don't think Rubens believed
it happened to the Son of God or felt it happened at all. A Ger-
man of the same age (“time” I mean) had
made a far ruder work which would have
brought tears to ones eyes. He didn't
believe it. Yet it is a wonderful
& a noble picture & a long ways
from his “Susannas” - 2 of them I am
sorry to say - which no gentleman could
have drawn.

There is a Cathedral here - wonderful
in its out side view appearance - The
one in Antwerp is wonderful inside
& beautiful & Majestic - the clear spring
of the groined arches in the middle
aisle is very impressive, & the entire
absence of pews - & - I am sorry to say - the
extreme paucity of worshipers adds
to the general effect of the interior.

I have some photographs - cards only - of
both places - which I will bring. I do not
feel like getting 6 cards 10 cents & pay-
ing 5 cents a piece to send them.

I have got Ned a pair of gloves 5.90 f.
& myself a pair for 4.25 that look part
just as good. I got him 7 1/2: I have 8 s
& they suit me, but he would consider them
too tight. I saw some wonderful glass
today that one might have bought-simply
for its beautty - only I could not carry it &
it was not cheap - some from Haida - in Bo-
hemia & some from France-

Oh, tell laura I saw a wonderful bunch
of Artificial Orchids, our “Shower of Gold”
& the large yellow & purple Catleyas
Does she remember how we looked for
them in San Jose. I thought they were
the natural flowers - they were in a bouquet
with Asparagus - on a corsage - I think
one calls it. The pansies too I could not
have told from real ones.- Both French,
Can't say that I have enjoyed seeing these
things quite as much as I expect to telling
of them. However I am glad I have
seen them. I did not see too much
& did not let myself get over fatigued
but I am fatigued.

Wish I were en route to Louisville,
Good night.
div1.closer:
Your affecate husband H. R. Carter Independently of “la grève” this
is an exceedingly difficult
Country to travel in, change cars so
often.
13) Back at Antwerp. I saw Mr
Smith. Did not get a chance to see the
pictures - although I could have done
so. The strike continues - so I
am en route to Hamburg - & will come
back later for Cherbourg & Havre
U I am certainly sorry to have my itinerary so broken in on- This job is disagreea-
ble enough without that.
“Backfish” was in the “Salatary
summer” or some subtitle by Eliza-
beth who had the German Garden,
